docs.lead_paragraph: I just spent a week with a fastidious woman who repeatedly cleaned her hands and every kitchen surface with soapy water, thoroughly washed every fruit and vegetable and dried them with paper towels and made sure that dish towels used to wipe hands did not also dry the clean dishes. At the time I thought that this behavior was a bit extreme -- until I reviewed the recommendations for safe handling of foods prepared in 1997 by the United States Departments of Agriculture and Health and Human Services and 10 food industry organizations.

headline.main: A Recipe for Disaster on Your Kitchen Counter

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column discusses food-handling safety in personal kitchen; Journal of the American Dietetic Assn reports that foodborne diseases cause estimated 76 million illnesses, 325,000 hospitalizations and 5,000 deaths in United States each year; study by Janet B Anderson, Utah State University affiliated dietitian, finds that in many kitchens hand washing and surface cleaning are inadequate to prevent disease; four steps to ensure safe food handling, discussed; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: I just spent a week with a fastidious woman who repeatedly cleaned her hands and every kitchen surface with soapy water, thoroughly washed every fruit and vegetable and dried them with paper towels and made sure that dish towels used to wipe hands...

docs.lead_paragraph: He came to my primary care clinic trim, tan and confused. While wintering in Florida, he learned that he had prostate cancer, a small tumor that had not spread.

headline.main: A Fine Line Between Ask And Tell

docs.abstract: Dr Peter A Ubel Cases article describes relatively new model of patient-doctor shared decision making; explains difficulties that can be encountered and suggests that because best course of treatment is different from patient to patient, doctors must learn about patient values not just physical condition (M)
docs.snippet: He came to my primary care clinic trim, tan and confused.    While wintering in Florida, he learned that he had prostate cancer, a small tumor that had not spread.

docs.lead_paragraph: Can a machine read a person's mind? A medical device company is about to find out. The company, Cyberkinetics Inc., plans to implant a tiny chip in the brains of five paralyzed people in an effort to enable them to operate a computer by thought alone.

headline.main: With Tiny Brain Implants, Just Thinking May Make It So

docs.abstract: Food and Drug Administration has approved clinical trial for brain implants designed to allow disabled individuals to move objects through thought; Dr John P Donoghue, Brown University neuroscience department chairman and founder of Cyberkinetics Inc, says implants are designed to allow people to substitute brain for hand; process of implantation and fine tuning of impulse messages discussed; Cyberkinetics chief executive Timothy R Surgenor contends product will be on market by 2007 or 2008; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Can a machine read a person's mind? A medical device company is about to find out.    The company, Cyberkinetics Inc., plans to implant a tiny chip in the brains of five paralyzed people in an effort to enable them to operate a computer by thought...

docs.lead_paragraph: Kangaroo care, a technique for soothing premature babies with skin-to-skin contact, can help calm babies born at full term as well, a study has concluded. In kangaroo care, parents are encouraged to hold their newborn children against their bare chests for extended periods. The technique, developed in Bolivia, has been found to reduce crying and agitation among premature babies in neonatal intensive care units.

headline.main: A Warm Welcome to the World

docs.abstract: Kangaroo care, technique involving direct skin to skin contact between parents and newborns, which has been used to effectivly sooth premature babies, is found to benefit babies not born early; Dr Sari Goldstein Ferber, University of Haifa, Israel, leads research that shows most newborn children benefit from technique, particularly in first two weeks before development of self-regulatory skills like finger sucking; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Kangaroo care, a technique for soothing premature babies with skin-to-skin contact, can help calm babies born at full term as well, a study has concluded.    In kangaroo care, parents are encouraged to hold their newborn children against their bare...

docs.lead_paragraph: Supplements containing lutein, a pigment found in dark green vegetables, improved the vision of men with age-related macular degeneration, a study has found. Age-related macular degeneration is the most common cause of vision loss in developed countries. Low levels of lutein consumption had previously been shown to be associated with higher risks for developing the disorder.

headline.main: For Failing Eyes, a Dose of Green

docs.abstract: Dr Stuart Richer of North Chicago, Ill, Veteran Affairs eye clinic publishes study in journal Optometry that shows age-related macular degeneration can be positively impacted by lutein-rich foods or lutein supplements; participating patients saw equivalent of one line better than start of study when given lutein for one year; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Supplements containing lutein, a pigment found in dark green vegetables, improved the vision of men with age-related macular degeneration, a study has found.     Age-related macular degeneration is the most common cause of vision loss in developed...

docs.lead_paragraph: On a languid March evening, Jeff Morris, a lean, muscular man with a calm smile and shaved head, led a class of three men and two women with slow, fluid, continuous movements through the formalized postures of tai chi, the centuries-old Chinese Taoist martial art. For 75 minutes, the participants focused their attention on controlling the positions of their arms, legs, torsos and spines, guiding them in concert repeatedly through their poses with varying degrees of gracefulness.

headline.main: Experts Assess the Merits of Meditation in Motion

docs.abstract: Medical community is investigating health benefits of tai chi, centuries-old Chinese martial art; Jeff Morris, who teaches tai chi at various Miami-Dade County locations, turned to exercise of mind and body in 1986 when he was diagnosed with full-blown AIDS; HIV is now barely detectable in his blood; studies have suggested health benefits for variety of diseases and disorders, but because tai chi is taught in many different forms, results are not conclusive; Dr Chenchen Wang, Tufts-New England Medical Center researcher whose study on medical use of tai chi appears in Archives of Internal Medicine, holds that potential benefits from discipline are high, but contends that not enough information is available to recommend it over other forms of exercise; photo (M)
docs.snippet: On a languid March evening, Jeff Morris, a lean, muscular man with a calm smile and shaved head, led a class of three men and two women with slow, fluid, continuous movements through the formalized postures of tai chi, the centuries-old Chinese...

docs.lead_paragraph: Boys who are gifted in math are better at using both hemispheres of the brain to solve problems than are students of average math ability, a study published yesterday concluded. The findings show that innate talent at mathematics is a result of a difference in brain functioning, said Dr. Michael W. O'Boyle of the University of Melbourne, an author of the study.

headline.main: Peering Into a Math Whiz's Brain

docs.abstract: Dr Michael W O'Boyle, University of Melbourne researcher, leads study that shows students excelling in mathematics make better use of both hemispheres of brain; findings are published in journal Neuropsychology; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Boys who are gifted in math are better at using both hemispheres of the brain to solve problems than are students of average math ability, a study published yesterday concluded.     The findings show that innate talent at mathematics is a result of a...

docs.lead_paragraph: A federal judge here cleared the way on Monday for a ban on the sale or manufacture of ephedra to start immediately. The judge denied a request by two manufacturers of the dietary supplement to delay the ban pending the outcome of a lawsuit. The manufacturers have sued the Food and Drug Administration and the Department of Health and Human Services.

headline.main: Judge Clears the Way For U.S. Ban on Ephedra

docs.abstract: United States District Court Judge Joel A Pisano denies request by NVE Pharmaceuticals and National Institute for Clinical Weight Loss to delay ban of ephedra by Food and Drug Administration (S)
docs.snippet: A federal judge here cleared the way on Monday for a ban on the sale or manufacture of ephedra to start immediately.     The judge denied a request by two manufacturers of the dietary supplement to delay the ban pending the outcome of a lawsuit. The...

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Transplant: From Myth to Reality,'' by Dr. Nicholas L. Tilney. Yale University Press, $30. ''Breathing for a Living: A Memoir,'' by Laura Rothenberg. Hyperion, $22.95. Organ transplantation has become almost routine since the first successful kidney transplant between identical twins in 1954.
docs.abstract: Dr Nicholas L Tilney, Harvard University surgery professor and transplant researcher, book Transplant: From Myth to Reality explores now routine practice of organ transplants; discusses variety of aspects, including commercialism and ethical conflicts, involved; Laura Rothenberg book Breathing for a Living: A Memoir follows her personal experience battling chronic and incurable lung disease and eventual failure of lung transplant that resulted in her death; photos (M)
docs.snippet: ''Transplant: From Myth to Reality,'' by Dr. Nicholas L. Tilney. Yale University Press, $30.    ''Breathing for a Living: A Memoir,'' by Laura Rothenberg. Hyperion, $22.95.      Organ transplantation has become almost routine since the first...

keywords.value: BREATHING FOR A LIVING: A MEMOIR (BOOK)

docs.lead_paragraph: Carlene Huesgen is not afraid of death, she says. Not since she felt herself slip from her body, float to a hospital ceiling and move toward a bright light three decades ago. ''I feel assured that there is life after death,'' said Ms. Huesgen, 61, who lives in Tucson. ''There really isn't such a thing as dying.''

headline.main: Following a Bright Light to a Calmer Tomorrow

docs.abstract: Near-death experiences are reported by 9 to 18 percent of people who have almost died; experience seems to have dramatic positive impact and Willoughby B Britton, University of Arizona doctoral student, has conducted study on factors influencing near-death reactions; findings, published in Psychological Science, identify neurological and psychological differences that suggest near-death experience patients are slightly healthier than others and have positive coping skills; Carlene Huesgen, who had near-death experience and took part in research, comments; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Carlene Huesgen is not afraid of death, she says. Not since she felt herself slip from her body, float to a hospital ceiling and move toward a bright light three decades ago.    ''I feel assured that there is life after death,'' said Ms. Huesgen, 61,...
